Award.AwardTitle: Detector Optimization for SuperCDMS and Other Experiments.
Award.AbstractNarration:
PROPOSAL NUMBER: 0801712
INSTITUTION: Santa Clara University
NSF PROGRAM: PHY - PARTICLE ASTROPHYSICS
PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR: Young, Betty A.

TITLE: Detector Optimization for SuperCDMS and Other Experiments.


ABSTRACT

Observations of galaxies, superclusters, distant supernovae and the cosmic microwave background radiation tell us that ~85% of the matter in the universe is not made of ordinary particles, but exists in some dark form. Deciphering the nature of this dark matter is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics. A leading hypothesis is that it is comprised of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) that were produced moments after the Big Bang. If WIMPs are the dark matter, then their presence in our Milky Way may be detectable via scattering from atomic nuclei in a terrestrial detector. The Cryogenic Dark Matter Search (CDMS) Collaboration has pioneered the use of low-temperature phonon-mediated detectors to detect the rare scattering of WIMPs on nuclei and distinguish them from backgrounds. With this powerful technology, operating deep underground in the Soudan mine in Minnesota, they have a world-leading effort with a projected sensitivity reach for 100 GeV/c2 WIMPs in CDMSII of a factor of eight beyond their best published limit.

This proposal from Santa Clara University requests base-program support which will allow for (a) the completion of the CDMSII experiment, which is fully constructed and acquiring science data at the Soudan Mine, (b) the testing and underground operation in the CDMSII infrastructure at Soudan of two new ?SuperTowers,? each comprised of six next-generation detectors, and (c) a modest effort of long-range R&D to develop and test new hardware and detectors for possible follow-up experiments.

Concerning Broader Impacts, the technical development will push the envelope of phonon-mediated detectors which have increasing applications. In addition, the SuperCDMS collaboration will continue its support of the public outreach program at Soudan, which hosts thousands of visitors each year for tours of the mine and laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is believed that at least 85% of the universe is made of material unlike the protons, neutrons and electrons that constitute the natural world we experience every day. Yet we know little about this 85% of the universe! The SCU group works on the Cryogenic Dark Matter Search (CDMS) experiment that develops and uses advanced physics technologies to directly search for Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) that are excellent candidates for a portion of this “unknown” mass of the universe. WIMPs are believed to exist for a number of sound scientific reasons. Unambiguous experimental proof that WIMPs exist, coupled with follow-up measurements to study their fundamental properties, would allow physicists to dramatically deepen humankind’s understanding of the nature of the universe.

The CDMS experiment, performed by a collaboration of ≈ 60 physicists and engineers from several universities and two National Labs, is one of only a few experiments in the world sensitive enough to detect and then study the nature of WIMPs. The CDMS experiment is housed about a half-mile underground in the Soudan Mine (Minnesota). This old iron mine was transformed into a research laboratory in the 1980’s. (The Soudan Mine is a fascinating historical site that the public can visit; underground tours are given regularly throughout the summer.) A handful of state-of-the-art physics experiments operate in the lab 24-hours a day. The major attraction of working in an underground laboratory is that the rock and dirt above the lab act as an effective shield from cosmic rays that would otherwise cause unwanted background signals in the experiments, rendering them nearly useless.

A lot of work goes into the preparation and operation of an experiment like CDMS. At the heart of our experiment are exceptionally sensitive energy-sensing detectors made from pure germanium. Ortec, an industry leader semiconductors, grows special germanium crystals just for us in their Oak Ridge, TN facilities. We take the as-grown crystalline material from Ortec and turn it into state-of-the-art detectors at the Stanford Nano-Fabrication Laboratory, a shared-use facility. About 50% of the users there are students. The CDMS detectors in Soudan were chiefly made by four Stanford collaborators, two of whom were SCU undergraduates.

CDMS detectors are instrumented with intricately patterned microscopic superconducting films that are screened by the SCU group by cooling the films to -459 oF. The SCU group is also responsible for working with Core Systems (in California), to ion-bombard the CDMS films when necessary to better optimize their superconducting properties. The detectors are then installed in a specialized refrigeration system (operating at -459 oF) in the Soudan Underground Laboratory where the main science experiment is carried out for months at a time. The CDMS experiment has evolved over the years and has reached such good sensitive that a deeper location will be needed soon to further advance our WIMP-detection studies.

Even beyond the scientific successes of CDMS to date there have been a multitude of student-training and development successes. Dozens of students and postdocs from several universities across the U.S. have been trained, hands-on, in important science and technology areas including nano-technology, advanced technical computing, state-of-the-art electronics, large-volume data processing, semiconductors, superconductivity, cryogenics, and more, as a direct result of CDMS funding by NSF (and DOE).
